response.answer_text: The close examination of GS paper 4 2018 question paper will amply clear the fact that for Ethics paper UPSC had started wading candidates in deep waters of theoretical underpinnings of topics mentioned in syllabus. Technical questions are being asked in jargon free simple language..see below question paper analysis and references from book as proof of the statement. Also the approach of cramming case studies like a weak students of maths who crams solutions and theorems instead of conceptual clarity will not work. This worked till previous year, and now may not yield impressive and rank improving marks. A interesting takeaway from Mains 2018 is reference book for GS paper 4 (Ethics, Integrity, and Aptitude in Governance) published by SAGE publicationsthatcovered directly 240 Marks from UPSC mains in 2018. Wonderfully one case study is similar pick from book discussing Clive Ponting case and the case study is one of parallax and not dilemma. CASE STUDY.Edward Snowden, a computer expert and former CIA administrator, released confidential Government documents to the press about the existence of Government surveillance programmes. According to many legal experts and the US Government, his action violated the Espionage act of 1971, which identified the leak of State secret as an act of treason. Yet, despite the fact that he broke the law, Snowden argued that he had a moral obligation to act. He gave a justification for his “whistle blowing” by stating that he had a duty “to inform the public as to that which is done in there name and that which is done against them.”According to Snowden, the Government’s violation of privacy had to be exposed regardless of legality since more substantive issues of social action and public morality were involved here. Many agreed with Snowden. Few argued that he broke the law and compromised national security, for which he should be held accountable.Doyou agree that Snowden’s actions were ethically justified even if legally prohibited? Why or why not?
